7.text:
In the years following the financial crisis,
the UK wasted £375bn on a failed scheme to

15.text:
stimulate the economy and end the recession.
This was one of the biggest missed opportunities

22.text: in history. Here’s how it happened.

26.text:
In 2009, the government wanted to get more
money into the economy to start a recovery.

33.text:
Now, there are two ways to get more money
into the economy.

37.text:
The usual way is to get banks to make more
loans. Every loan a bank makes creates brand

44.text:
new money. So when people borrow more, more
money is created.

50.text:
But there was just one problem. In 2009, banks
weren’t lending. They were terrified that

57.text:
their existing loans wouldn’t be repaid,
so they weren’t willing to make new ones.

62.text:
So if banks aren’t creating enough money,
the Bank of England can step in to create

68.text:
money instead. As Mervyn King, then-Governor
of the Bank of England explained:

73.text:
“A damaged banking system means that today
banks aren’t creating enough money. We have

79.text: to do it for them.” [Mervyn King]

82.text:
From 2009, the Bank of England started a scheme
called Quantitative Easing. They electronically

89.text:
created £375bn of new money, to stimulate
the economy. That’s nearly £6000 for every

98.text: man, woman and child in the UK.

102.text:
But instead of giving this money to the government
or even to ordinary people, the Bank of England

108.text:
put this £375bn straight into the financial
markets. By flooding the markets with newly

116.text:
created money it pushed up share prices by
20%.

121.text:
The big idea was that people who owned shares
would feel wealthier and would then go out

126.text:
into the economy and spend more. The money
would trickle down, and eventually everyone

135.text:
But most people don’t own many shares. In
fact, 40% of the stock market is owned by

142.text:
just the wealthiest 5% of the population.
These people became richer by £128,000 per

151.text:
household. But they didn’t go out and spend
more: instead, they put even more money into

157.text:
the financial markets to benefit from rising
prices.

161.text:
So Quantitative Easing didn’t work. For
every £1 the Bank of England created in this

168.text:
way, just 8p trickled down to the real economy.
The rest of the money got trapped in the financial

176.text:
markets, making the rich even richer, but
doing very little to help anybody else.

183.text:
Meanwhile, at the same time as the Bank of
England was creating all this new money, the

189.text: government was running out of money.

192.text:
In 2010 they cancelled a program to rebuild
715 schools. They also cancelled plans to

200.text:
build over 1,000 flood defence projects. At
the same time, tens of thousands of construction

206.text:
workers were unemployed, sat at home desperately
looking for work and for something useful

211.text:
to do. Instead of using some of the new money
to employ them to build good schools – which

217.text:
would have cost just £1bn - we let the Bank
of England create 375 times this amount just

228.text:
So why does the government cancel essential
projects because “there’s no money”,

233.text:
even though the Bank of England was able to
create more new money than the entire government

242.text:
What if the Bank of England had taken just
a fraction of the money they’d created,

246.text: and put it into the real economy?

249.text: This is an idea that we call Sovereign Money.

253.text:
Instead of relying on private banks to create
money to push up house prices, or letting

257.text:
the Bank of England create money to flood
financial markets, we could use the power

263.text:
to create money in the public interest – to
improve our economy, to build better homes,

270.text:
better infrastructure, cleaner energy, more
jobs or whatever we democratically decide

277.text:
If the Bank of England had taken just £10bn
– less than 3% of what they actually created

284.text:
– and given it to the government to spend
into the economy,

288.text:
the recession would have been over much sooner,
and hundreds of thousands of people could

292.text: have been saved from years of unemployment.

297.text:
By spending £10bn on building affordable
homes, the government could have created up

303.text:
to 284,000 jobs. And as those new employees
go out and spend their salaries, this would

310.text: create even more spending and more jobs.

315.text:
So when new money goes into financial markets
through Quantitative Easing, it takes £1

321.text: to grow the economy by just 8 pence.

325.text:
But when new money goes into real economy,
then every £1 created grows the economy by

332.text:
There is a better way to use the power to
create money. Instead of using it to prop

340.text:
up financial markets or push up house prices,
we can make sure the power to create money

346.text:
is used for something that benefits ordinary
people.

350.text:
We’re campaigning for a financial system
that works for society and not against it.
